title: tonynewham
author: tonynewham
content: Hello you very wonderful and intelligent people that make up this forum, i truly hope you have had a wonderful weekend and that you are happy and healthy. I am very interested in using Bisq to purchase Bitcoins, which is a decentralized, blockchain-powered cryptocurrency exchange. I am wanting to remain as anonymous as possible and please wondered would it be okay to use a VPN to mask my real IP address when using Bisq please, would this still work please?Lastly i have heard about people setting up there own nodes on Bisq, would this make the transaction more anonymous or is this basically to keep the transaction more secure so you do not get scammed please? The transaction i am making is only $40 would my own node not my required please?If anyone kindly had any thoughts on the two questions above i would be immensely thankful and highly appreciative for your support with this. My heart would go out to you and i would be so thankful.Thank you very much for any support you can give. I truly hope you have a very happy and wonderful week ahead. Sending you lots of good wishes and i truly hope you have a wonderful and amazing life, for you, family and friends. With my every best wishes.

comments.author: Bitcoin_Arena
comments.body: Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PMI am very interested in using Bisq to purchase Bitcoins, which is a decentralized, blockchain-powered cryptocurrency exchange. I am wanting to remain as anonymous as possible and please wondered would it be okay to use a VPN to mask my real IP address when using Bisq please, would this still work please?You don't even need a VPN, the service connects to the Bitcoin network via Tor by default.QuoteLastly i have heard about people setting up there own nodes on Bisq, would this make the transaction more anonymous or is this basically to keep the transaction more secure so you do not get scammed please? Running an own node is more to do with decentralization to the platform. With decentralization comes anonymity. About getting scammed, you just have to follow the instructions provided on how to perform a p2p trade. You will be safe.QuoteThe transaction i am making is only $40 would my own node not my required please? Sorry I didn't understand this part.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PM The transaction i am making is only $40 would my own node not my required please?it's just $40 so there's no need in running your own node.And you should be aware that bisq requires a minimum of 0.0001BTC as deposit to make any trade.And No it's not really vital to use VPN since bisq has a Tor system connected.You can try peach Bitcoin as an alternative is Europe based And doesn't require KYC for transactions less than 1000CAD(around $1200)

comments.author: Upgrade00
comments.body: Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PMI am wanting to remain as anonymous as possible and please wondered would it be okay to use a VPN to mask my real IP address when using Bisq please, would this still work please?As bisq is run over Tor, it makes it unnecessary to use a VPN as well. It's also very easy for you to make a mistake while using a VPN and unintentionally make yourself less anonymous. Best to stick to Tor.Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PMLastly i have heard about people setting up there own nodes on Bisq, would this make the transaction more anonymous or is this basically to keep the transaction more secure so you do not get scammed please? Your own node makes you more anonymous (and nut more secure).It doesn't matter if youreonly trading $40 now. If you plan to make future trades and care deeply about anonymity, you should consider running your own node.

comments.author: satscraper
comments.created_time: Today at 07:54:13 AMLast edit: Today at 08:20:35 AM by satscraper
comments.body: Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PMI am very interested in using Bisq to purchase Bitcoins, which is a decentralized, blockchain-powered cryptocurrency exchange. I am wanting to remain as anonymous as possible and please wondered would it be okay to use a VPN to mask my real IP address when using Bisq please, would this still work please?As it was already mentioned in this thread  Bisq client installed  on your machine connects to the given network via TOR automatically, as the relevant software needed to do this is distributed with Bisq packet  but I use VPN to mask my TOR traffic having in fact TOR via VPN connection. Works perfectly, regarding to Bisq.Quote from: tonynewham on March 24, 2025, 12:28:53 PMLastly i have heard about people setting up there own nodes on Bisq, would this make the transaction more anonymous or is this basically to keep the transaction more secure so you do not get scammed please? The transaction i am making is only $40 would my own node not my required please?Probably you meant your own node of Bitcoin Core as Bisq node will be launched automatically as soon as you launch Bisq software on your machine.Though " Bisq users can still choose to connect to arbitrary public nodes" the use of your  own  Bitcoin Core node is preferable if you care of your privacyQuote from: https://docs.bisq.network/btcnodeRegarding  $40 valued transaction. Bisq node is required to run no matter what is the value of your transaction, either $40, or less, or more. Nevertheless, take into account that you will need to use the collateral to buy Bitcoin on Bisq. If you don't want to provide collateral when buying bitcoin then it is better to  use Bisq2 rather then Bisq. On Bisq2 which is reputation based rather than collateral-based trading platform you may find traders who will agree to trade with you even when your reputation equals to zero.BTW, I run my own Bitcoin Core node alongside with bisq and bisq2 and trade on both bisq and bisq2.

comments.author: tonynewham
comments.body: Thank you very much for all your wonderful and amazing replies, you are all wonderful human beings here. Thank you ever so much for helping me outs its really appreciated and this has all started to make alot more sense. I really appreciate your time. I please have two quick questions i have thoughts of, i feel embarrassed and anxious to ask, however if you are able to help, i would be forever grateful and thankful. I know Bisq requires a minimum of 0.0001BTC as deposit, i please wondered what options i have to purchase this anonymously the initial bitcoin deposit please, as i know alot of decentralized bitcoin exchange networks require a deposit? If anyone kindly had any thoughts on this i would be forever grateful and thankful, it would mean the world to me.Lastly i know Bisq accepts Revolut as a payment method, which will capture your credit card details, i please wondered, is your Revolut details not stored on any of Bisq's software please in relation to any transactions? If anyone kindly had any thoughts on this i would be forever thankful and i would be immensely appreciative for your support.Thank you very much for your time, i truly hope you have a very happy and memorable rest of the week. Sending you lots of good wishes and i truly hope you continue to have a wonderful and amazing life. With my every best wishes.

comments.author: d5000
comments.body: Quote from: tonynewham on Today at 03:56:52 PMI know Bisq requires a minimum of 0.0001BTC as deposit, i please wondered what options i have to purchase this anonymously the initial bitcoin deposit please, as i know alot of decentralized bitcoin exchange networks require a deposit?Indeed this is quite a challenge. The website kycnot.me lists some options for centralized P2P exchanges. Some well known options are Peach Bitcoin which was already mentioned above, and HodlHodl. There you can trade pseudonymous, but yes you're trading supervised by a centralized entity and you have to trust this entity to not scrape too much data from you (I think both are non-custodial so your funds should be safe).There's also a section in this forum, Currency Exchange, where you can post an offer. You can also try to mine some altcoins and then exchange them to BTC. Or to sell something for Bitcoin, if you offer an attractive price it could work.Quote from: tonynewham on Today at 03:56:52 PMLastly i know Bisq accepts Revolut as a payment method, which will capture your credit card details, i please wondered, is your Revolut details not stored on any of Bisq's software please in relation to any transactions?I'm not a Bisq expert but I think the IBAN itself is not stored on the network, but a hash of the IBAN and other account details is (for security reasons, to prevent people being able to accumulate account age with stolen bank accounts).Of course your trading partner however would see your bank data when he receives your Revolut transfer.

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Quote from: tabar94415 on Today at 06:09:24 AMHello! It's wonderful to connect with you, and I appreciate your kind words. I hope you're having a great week as well. Let's address your questions about using Bisq with a focus on anonymity and node usage.Using a VPN with BisqYes, using a VPN with Bisq is a common practice for those seeking to enhance their privacy. A VPN masks your real IP address, making it more difficult to trace your internet activity back to your physical location. Here's a breakdown:   How it helps:It hides your IP address from your internet service provider (ISP) and other potential observers.   It adds a layer of privacy by routing your internet traffic through an encrypted tunnel.Important considerations:Choose a reputable VPN provider that prioritizes privacy and has a strict no-logs policy.Be aware that even with a VPN, complete anonymity is not guaranteed. Other factors, like your operating system configuration and browser usage, can still reveal information.Using a VPN in conjunction with the tor network, could increase your anonymity.Bisq Nodes and AnonymityRunning your own Bisq node serves a different purpose than simply increasing transaction anonymity. Here's how it works:Node functionality:Bisq is a peer-to-peer (P2P) network. Running a node means you're contributing to the network by relaying transaction information.Nodes help maintain the decentralized nature of Bisq.Running a node allows you to use your own local copy of the Bisq software and data, rather than relying on a remote server.Anonymity vs. Security:Running a node doesn't significantly increase the anonymity of your individual transactions. The core anonymity comes from Bisq's P2P design and the use of Tor.However, running a node enhances the overall security and resilience of the Bisq network, which indirectly benefits all users.Running your own node does provide a level of increased security, by eliminating the risk of a malicious 3rd party server.For a $40 transaction:For a small transaction like $40, running your own node is not strictly necessary. You can use Bisq effectively without one.The main benifit of running a node is to support the network, and to increase your own personal security. can you not make it any more obvious that this is AI generated  The confidence to post a wall of AI response amazes me. Quote from: tonynewham on Today at 03:56:52 PMLastly i know Bisq accepts Revolut as a payment method, which will capture your credit card details, i please wondered, is your Revolut details not stored on any of Bisq's software please in relation to any transactions? If anyone kindly had any thoughts on this i would be forever thankful and i would be immensely appreciative for your support. No it doesn't. If it did save customers data. It wouldn't be this popular or considered a decentralized system  Instead it is saved locally in your device And only your trading partner can see it.QuoteI know Bisq requires a minimum of 0.0001BTC it's actually 0.001BTC
